paper_title: Insights into the role of MgAl layered double oxides interlayer in Pt/TiO2 toward photocatalytic CO2 reduction

catalyst.source: The representative TiO 2 loaded with cocatalyst (e.g., Pt) have been used extensively for the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction in solar-to-chemical energy conversion.
catalyst.context: The representative TiO 2 loaded with cocatalyst (e.g., Pt) have been used extensively for the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction in solar-to-chemical energy conversion.However, it still suffers from low efficiency, due to the weak adsorption/activation of CO 2 .In this work, an MgAl layered double oxides (MgAl-LDO) was successfully introduced into the interface of Pt/TiO 2 , by in-situ deposition of MgAl layered double hydroxides and subsequent high temperature calcination.The structure, optical property and the photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction of as-fabricated Pt/MgAl-LDO/TiO 2 were experimentally investigated.Especially, the roles of MgAl-LDO during the CO 2 reduction process were highlighted.It concluded MgAl-LDO possessed Lewis acidic and Lewis basic bifunctional roles that enhanced the performance of the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.The optimal yields of CO and CH 4 of Pt/MgAl-LDO/TiO 2 exhibited ca. 2 and 11 times as high as that of Pt/TiO 2 , respectively.The adsorption states of CO 2 and the adsorbed species in the course of photoreduction of CO 2 with H 2 O vapor on Pt/MgAl-LDO/TiO 2 were examined by insitu infrared spectroscopy.Monodentate carbonate (m-CO 3 2A) and monodentate bicarbonate (m-HCO 3 A ) were found to be the main surface species that adsorbed.In the presence of H 2 O, m-CO 3 2A species could be readily converted to active m-HCO 3 A intermediate, which was subsequently transformed into surface CO 2 A. This was attributed to the fact that MgAl-LDO contains much more strong Lewis basic sits for CO 2 adsorption to produce m-CO 3 2A and the Lewis acid sites for the dissociation of H 2 O into H and OH groups.Moreover, photoluminescence spectra further indicated that oxygen vacancy existed in the interface of MgAl-LDO/TiO 2 , which facilitated the photogenerated charges separation and also contributed to the enhanced photocatalytic performance.As a result, the Lewis acidic-basic characteristics of MgAl-LDO, as well as the improved charges separation, should be responsible for the increased photocatalytic activity of Pt/MgAl-LDO/TiO 2 toward CO 2 reduction.

catalyst.source: TiO 2 nanorods were prepared by a modified hydrothermal method.
catalyst.context: TiO 2 nanorods were prepared by a modified hydrothermal method.Typically, 6 mL HCl was dropped into 15 mL titanium isopropoxide in a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave at room temperature, and then the mixture was sealed and kept at 180 C for 36 h.After being cooled to room temperature, the resulting white precipitates were filtered out and washed with diluent NaOH solution followed by water until the filtrate became neutral.The products were finally dried overnight in vacuum at 80 C. For preparing MgAl-LDH colloidal solution, glycine intercalated MgAl-LDH (Gly-MgAl-LDH) was first fabricated.Typically, 60 mL aqueous solution containing Mg(NO 3 ) 2 A6H 2 O and Al(NO 3 ) 3 A9H 2 O (Mg 2 Al 3 0.5 mol L A1 , Mg/Al 3:1) was added dropwise into 100 mL glycine (0.5 mol L A1 ) under continuous Ar flow.At same time, 2 mol L A1 NaOH was used to maintain the solution's pH at 10.After Mg-Al solution was completely added, the mixture was kept pH at 10 under vigorous stir for another 6 h.The slurry was then aged for 12 h, followed by centrifuged at 12,000 rpm.The obtained precipitates were washed with water for five times and dried overnight at 80 C.MgAl-LDH colloidal solution was obtained by exfoliation of Gly-MgAl-LDH.In typical, 0.5 g Gly-MgAl LDH was dispersed into 100 mL water (pH 4, adjusted by 0.1 mol L A1 HCl) and then was stirred vigorously at room temperature for 24 h, and finally centrifuged at 5000 rpm to exclude the residual. MgAl-LDH/TiO 2 was first fabricated by in-situ deposition method.Typically, the desired volumes (1, 2, 5 and 10 mL) of MgAl-LDH colloidal solution was added into 5 mL water containing 0.1 g TiO 2 .The mixture was then dried at 80 C with continuous stirring.The final particles were subsequently calcined in air at 450 C for 4 h to prepare MgAl-LDO/TiO 2 .The as-prepared MgAl-LDO/TiO 2 was marked as MgAl-LDO/TiO 2 -n, where n 1, 2, 5 and 10, corresponding to the added volumes of MgAl LDH colloidal solution. For comparison, MgO/TiO 2 , Al 2 O 3 /TiO 2 and MgO-Al 2 O 3 /TiO 2 were prepared by using impregnation method.Typically, 0.1 g TiO 2 was immersed in a given amount of 5 mmol L A1 Mg(NO 3 ) 2 with ultrasonic and stir, and then dried at 80 C under stirring.The sample was finally calcined in air at 450 C for 4 h, thus MgO/TiO 2 was received.Instead of Mg(NO 3 ) 2 with Al(NO 3 ) 3 or Mg(NO 3 ) 2 -Al(NO 3 ) 3 , Al 2 O 3 /TiO 2 and MgO-Al 2 O 3 /TiO 2 were also obtained.The loading amounts of MgO and Al 2 O 3 were referenced to that of MgAl-LDO/TiO 2 -2, in which the amounts of MgO and Al 2 O 3 were 1.9 wt and 0.73 wt (form ICP-AES results) respectively.MgAl-LDO/TiO 2 -mix was prepared by mechanically mixing TiO 2 and MgAl-LDO derived from MgAl-LDH under 450 C. Cocatalysts of 1 wtPt were loaded on TiO 2 -based samples by an in-situ photodeposition method, using H 2 PtCl 6 A6H 2 O as precursors.Taking Pt/TiO 2 as an example, 0.1 TiO 2 was suspended in 25 mL H 2 PtCl 6 solution containing 0.01 molAL A1 methanol as hole scavenger.The suspension was irradiated with a 300 W Xe lamp for 1 h.The sample was then recovered by filtration, followed by washed repeatedly with water and dried at 80 C overnight. The crystalline phases were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) on a Bruker D8 Advance powder diffractometer using Cu Ka radiation (operating voltage: 40 kV, operating current: 20 mA, scan rate: 5/min).UV-visible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS) were recorded on a UV-vis 2600 spectrophotometer (SHIMADZA) and calibrated with Kubelka-Munk method.The morphology was examined by a JSM-7610F scanning electron microscopy (SEM) at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV.Elemental analysis was collected by energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, OXFORD X-act) on the SEM (accelerating voltage: 20 kV, probe current: 0.02 mA, Time: 300 s).Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution TEM (HRTEM) were performed on a JEOL JEM-2010 TEM (Japan) with the accelerating voltage of 200 kV.The contents of metal elements were determined by an inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES, Optima DV2100, PerkinElmer, USA).Steady-state photoluminescence (PL) spectra were carried out on a FLS980 fluorescence spectrometer (Edinburgh, excitation source, 450 W Xe lamp; excitation wavelength, 350 nm).Specific surface area was analyzed by nitrogen adsorption-desorption at 77 K using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method (Micromeritics, ASAP 2020).Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker VERTEX 70 spectrometer in 4000-400 cm A1 using pressed KBr pellet method. The infrared spectra of CO 2 adsorption were recorded with a resolution of 4 cm A1 using 16 scans on a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (Nicolet NEXUS 470) with a MCT detector.The experiments were carried out using a special IR cell in conjunction with a vacuum system.Typically, 20 mg of catalyst was first pressed into a self-supporting thin wafer (15 mm diameter) and then was transferred to the sample holder in the special IR cell.The wafer was evacuated at 350 C for 2 h to remove the adsorbed molecules, and then cooled down to room temperature for recording the background spectrum of the sample.CO 2 was introduced to the cell and followed by degassing before recording the IR spectrum of adsorbed CO 2 .The pretreatment of sample for IR spectra with pyridine adsorption was similar to that of IR for CO 2 adsorption.Typically, 20 mg of the sample was evacuated at 350 C for 1 h to remove the impurities in the cell, and then the background spectrum of the sample was recorded.After introducing the pyridine vapor for 15 min followed by being degassed under vacuum at 150 C for 30 min, the spectrum was recorded. In-situ IR spectra for the coadsorption of CO 2 and H 2 O before and after UV irradiation were recorded with a Nicolet (NEXUS 470) spectrophotometer in the range 4000-1000 cm A1 with a resolution of 4 cm A1 .The pretreatment of sample was identical to IR of CO 2 adsorption.The wafer was evacuated at 350 C for 1 h to remove the adsorbed molecules, and then was cooled down to room temperature for recording the background spectrum.Subsequently, CO 2 and H 2 O were introduced to IR cell at room temperature and followed by degassing for 1 h and subsequently under UV irradiation for 1 h at room temperature to record the corresponding spectra.Spectra of the adsorbed species were obtained by subtracting the catalyst spectrum. The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O was carried out using gas-solid mode in a Pyrex reaction cell connected to a closed gas circulation and evacuation system.The light source was a topirradiated 300 W Xe lamp (LS-SXE300 CUV, Beijing Perfectlight Technology Co. Ltd).Typically, 20 mg of catalyst was evenly dis-persed onto a glass-sheet (1.5 cm A 2 cm), and then was placed on the holder in the upper region of the reactor, in which 40 mL water was charged on the bottom in advance.The light intensity at the location of catalyst was 4.3 mW cm A2 for 260-400 nm measured by an UV irradiatometer with a Si photodiode (Shenzhen Linshang).The reactor was sealed and degassed for 30 min, and then CO 2 was bubbled slowly till the pressure up to 1 atm.Finally, the reaction was conducted under light irradiation at 20 C for 8 h.The generated CO and CH 4 , as well as H 2 and O 2 , were determined by an on-line GC 7900 gas chromatograph (Shanghai Tianmei) equipped with methanator, flame ionization detector (FID) and thermal conductivity detector (TCD), and the relative standard deviations for the amounts of H 2 , CO and CH 4 formed were 5.

co-catalyst.context: The representative TiO 2 loaded with cocatalyst (e.g., Pt) have been used extensively for the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction in solar-to-chemical energy conversion.However, it still suffers from low efficiency, due to the weak adsorption/activation of CO 2 .In this work, an MgAl layered double oxides (MgAl-LDO) was successfully introduced into the interface of Pt/TiO 2 , by in-situ deposition of MgAl layered double hydroxides and subsequent high temperature calcination.The structure, optical property and the photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction of as-fabricated Pt/MgAl-LDO/TiO 2 were experimentally investigated.Especially, the roles of MgAl-LDO during the CO 2 reduction process were highlighted.It concluded MgAl-LDO possessed Lewis acidic and Lewis basic bifunctional roles that enhanced the performance of the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.The optimal yields of CO and CH 4 of Pt/MgAl-LDO/TiO 2 exhibited ca. 2 and 11 times as high as that of Pt/TiO 2 , respectively.The adsorption states of CO 2 and the adsorbed species in the course of photoreduction of CO 2 with H 2 O vapor on Pt/MgAl-LDO/TiO 2 were examined by insitu infrared spectroscopy.Monodentate carbonate (m-CO 3 2A) and monodentate bicarbonate (m-HCO 3 A ) were found to be the main surface species that adsorbed.In the presence of H 2 O, m-CO 3 2A species could be readily converted to active m-HCO 3 A intermediate, which was subsequently transformed into surface CO 2 A.
